docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER you watch the videotape of Red Sox catcher Carlton Fisk waving his fly ball fair for a home run in Game 6 of the 1975 World Series, do you remember that Pat Darcy was the Cincinnati Reds' pitcher in that 12th inning? Do you remember Dave Stenhouse, a Washington Senators right-hander who was the American League starter in 1962's second All-Star Game?

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Remembering Players M.L.B. Has Forgotten

docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses class-action lawsuit brought against Major League Baseball for more than 1,000 cases where MLB and players union have not vested players for pension or medical coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress will act if Major League Baseball's leaders fail to strengthen and expand the sport's drug-testing policy, Senator John McCain warned Wednesday. McCain, an Arizona Republican, said during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing that he did not know which legislative steps could be imposed on baseball, but he added, ''We will have to act some way unless the major league players union acts in the affirmative and rapid fashion.''
docs.abstract: Senator John McCain warns Major League Baseball during Commerce Committe hearing that Congress will act if baseball cannot successfully negotiate stricter drug testing policies; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Congress will act if Major League Baseball's leaders fail to strengthen and expand the sport's drug-testing policy, Senator John McCain warned Wednesday.    McCain, an Arizona Republican, said during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing that he did...

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE interrogating the union boss Donald Fehr on baseball's toothless drug policy, Senator John McCain all but asked Fehr if he wanted a cigarette -- like the Marlboros that Gene Orza has declared are no worse than steroids. With Fehr two weeks removed from gallbladder surgery, his face reflected the white of a lab coat, but he refused to wear lambskin. He offered no hint of vulnerability in front of the ravenous senators at a Commerce Committee hearing yesterday in Washington. He had the stamina to remain stubborn when McCain challenged him to commit himself to the kind of comprehensive program that the National Football League maintains, rather than the pacifying facade outlined in baseball's 2002 collective bargaining agreement.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; It's a Curious Way To Play Truth or Dare

docs.abstract: Selena Roberts Sports of The Times column contends that Senator John McCain's scolding of Major League Baseball players union and its leader Donald Fehr is no more than election-year showboating; asserts that Fehr is wise to remain as silent as possible on issue of drug policy until government produces evidence of one steroid-using athlete (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The framed poster in the nurse practitioner's office lists ''101 Ways to Say No to Sex.'' But Tabitha F., a 17-year-old high school senior, wants to say yes without apology. ''I guess I'm a feminist, because I don't believe having sexual freedom is bad, dirty,'' she declared during a break between Spanish and A.P. Lit, where she was reading ''The Awakening,'' an 1899 novel about a woman's emancipation. ''I think it's all about being ready, and not to go there without a helmet.''

headline.main: For a Promising but Poor Girl, A Struggle Over Sex and Goals

docs.abstract: Second of two articles Young Love, New Caution cites example of Tabitha, promising but poor 17-year-old high school senior who lives in New York City homeless shelter, in warning of threats posed by poverty to national crusade to prevent teenage pregnancy; she cites cost as reason she stopped using birth control patch obtained through pregnancy prevention clinic at her Bronx high school, clinic that itself is threatened with cutbacks; graphs of link between poverty and pregnancy and age of men with whom teenage mothers have children; photos (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: CAN Canadian Internet pharmacists provide a cure for high prescription drug prices in the United States? Or are they part of the problem? American regulators and lawmakers are split on the issue, even as the pharmaceutical industry continues trying to fight Canadian drug wholesalers and online retailers who have carved out a market south of the border. Online Canadian Web sites have made hundreds of millions of dollars selling American-made prescription drugs to Americans in the last few years, but growth in the market flattened this year because drug makers have begun restricting sales to Canadian wholesalers. Also, the Food and Drug Administration has stepped up its warnings to consumers on the hazards of importing prescription drugs, even those that were originally exported from the United States to Canada.

headline.main: E-Commerce; As the debate continues, opinions are divided over the merits of allowing online drug purchases from Canada.

docs.abstract: Canadian Internet sales of prescription drugs to US, which ran into hundreds of millions of dollars in last few years, have turned flat this year because drug makers have begun restricting sales to Canadian wholesalers and because FDA has stepped up its warnings to consumers on hazards of importing prescription drugs, even those originally exported from US to Canada; drug makers and FDA also contend that importation of drugs from Canada is illegal; Canadian companies find powerful allies in governors, mayors and county executives, who are publicly declaring that at least online outlets are safe; photo (M)
